Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Statistical Learning Algorithms for Micro-Event Time Series Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is focused on the development of new data analysis tools for analyzing personal data archives, namely, the streams of digital data that are routinely recorded reflecting different aspects of individuals' daily lives. Examples of such data include keystrokes, email histories, text messages, social media interactions, microblogs, as well as records of physical activity, diet, and sleep. As sensors become more accurate and cheaper and as data storage becomes effectively zero cost, there is increasing demand for data analysis tools that allow individuals to analyze and gain insight into their own personal data. This research project is developing new statistical machine learning algorithms for analyzing these types of data. The project has a particular focus on the development of models and algorithms to handle personal archives in the form of event time-series data, consisting of logs of time-stamped events involving interactions with other individuals as well as textual and other metadata. Testbed data sets being used to support this research include publicly-available archives of email histories, software development discussions, Twitter microblogs, Wikipedia editing interactions, and physical proximity data. In terms of broader societal impact, the data analysis tools being developed by this project have the potential to significantly transform how individuals analyze their personal data to better understand and monitor their physical and mental health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data in the form of time-stamped events related to human activity is increasingly common across domains such as medicine, education, social media, e-commerce, and more. This type of data is typically very large, complex, and noisy - and as a result it has been difficult to visualize and understand such data using traditional data analysis approaches. The research in this project focused on the development of new machine learning methods that allow us to better understand, analyze, and make predictions with this form of data. 


The project developed a range of different types of methods and algorithms. As an example, one of the algorithms developed can analyze complex historical data on how individuals interact in social networks (such as email communication within a company). The algorithm automatically extracts naturally-occurring clusters or groups of individuals from a network and characterizes how these groupings evolve over time. This allows for visualization and prediction of complex data that can contain potentially millions of events (well beyond our capacity to directly visualize or understand). Another algorithm developed as part of this project is able to analyze large datasets of geolocated social media data to produce accurate maps of aggregate human activity, providing rich and timely information that complements more traditional methods of spatial data collection such as the census.


In a number of research papers produced by the project, applications of these algorithms were demonstrated for a variety of problems, including visualization and understanding of students' learning behavior over time in education research, generation of more accurate recommendation systems for personalization in e-commerce, and models that provide insight into spatio-temporal patterns related to urban crime. The project also produced publicly-available software and datasets that can be used by other researchers and by the commercial world to develop and systematically evaluate new algorithms and methods for large-scale event data.


Last Modified: 01/25/2019
Modified by: Padhraic Smyth
